fullProgramDescription: The Political Science major provides students with a broad understanding of the discipline, including American politics, comparative politics, international relations, and political theory. Students develop critical thinking, research, and analytical skills through coursework and research opportunities.
shortProgramDescription: The Political Science B.A. at UCLA provides a comprehensive education in the field, preparing students for careers in government, law, public policy, and more.
classHighlights: The major requires foundational courses in American Politics (POL SCI 40), Comparative Politics (POL SCI 120), International Relations (POL SCI 140), and Political Theory (POL SCI 180), ensuring a broad base of knowledge.

Students choose from a range of upper-division courses, including POL SCI 150 (Globalization and Governance), POL SCI 191 (Introduction to Research Design), and various electives in subfields like public policy, urban politics, or comparative politics.
Courses cover a range of methodologies, including quantitative analysis and qualitative research techniques, preparing students for advanced study or professional careers.
Electives allow students to explore specialized topics, such as environmental politics, social movements, or the politics of specific regions or countries.
The major emphasizes developing critical thinking, writing, and analytical skills through coursework and research opportunities.
learningOutcomes: Understand the fundamental concepts and theories in political science.
Analyze and interpret data related to political phenomena.
Develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
Communicate complex ideas effectively in written and oral form.
Apply knowledge of political science to real-world issues and problems.
Demonstrate an understanding of the diversity of political systems and institutions.
additionalInformation: Students must fulfill the College's general education requirements and complete a minimum of 180 units to graduate. The major is flexible, allowing students to tailor their coursework to their interests.
